Saikiran Krishnamurthy
Saikiran Krishnamurthy
   • 3rd+
Verified • 3rd+
Co-founder & CEO, xto10x Technologies
Co-founder & CEO, xto10x Technologies
2mo • 
 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
How do you get your business ready for public market performance?

Our first retreat of theIPO Academy kicked off with a session on business readiness, featuring the founders of three listed startups -of Awfis,of Ixigo, andof PolicyBazaar - all outperformers in the public markets.

Amit shared how Awfis survived COVID, and eventually turned around via its “Managed Aggregator” model, which has a 70+% ROCE. By the time it listed, it delivered consistent progress on all key metrics (# of centers, ROCE, utilization etc.).

Ixigo filed their DRHP in 2021 and conducted roadshows, but ultimately delayed their IPO due to macro headwinds. Aloke shared why this was a blessing in disguise - it established a baseline for investors, helped refine the narrative based on roadshow feedback, and got Ixigo to start behaving like a public company (strong IDs, AOP discipline, etc.). Their listing in 2024 went smoothly as a result.

Alok, who was the CFO during PB’s listing, broke down the readiness journey into a 50+ point checklist: covering everything founders need to do from 2Y pre-listing to post-IPO, going as far as sharing contacts of key individuals (lawyers, bankers, consultants) who can help in various steps.

What stood out was they disagreed a lot! Whether to hire agencies for IR. How to work with auditors. The role of domestic & international lawyers. These sparked lively debates among faculty and participants alike. And that was the magic of the session: it wasn’t about the one right answer - but about the range of paths to readiness and the trade-offs involved in each.

Despite the differences, the end-state for readiness was strikingly similar:
1. A differentiated business model with superior operating performance to peers
2. Consistency in performance via strong input-output equations for P&L drivers
3. A simple narrative that captures the uniqueness
4. Transparency on the "beating heart" metrics
5. A price that attracts the right investors

These themes also appear consistently in the one-on-one work we do with companies headed to IPO. Some recurring observations:

- Founders often take their uniqueness for granted and don't do justice to it in their narrative. For example, one company built a narrative around its product & customers. These are good, but the real differentiator was its proven acquisition engine. This simple shift in framing changed how they track input metrics and allocate resources.
- The “beating heart” metrics are often not linked with financial performance. For example, a company had great retention and organic growth but this did not translate into high EBITDA or cash flow growth. An investigation into the “why” revealed the importance of cost focus and operating leverage.

Coming soon: Org readiness!

It was our privilege to host you Vipul Shinghal - thanks so much for joining us and sharing your leadership lessons from a lifetime of service in the Indian Army - three lessons in particular stayed with me:

1. Senior leaders don't react, they respond (with due consideration)
2. Never underestimate the power of a good story (they go further than instructions!)
3. Character and values are so much more fundamental than competence

Hope to have you back with us soon!

Vipul Shinghal
Vipul Shinghal
Vipul Shinghal
   • 3rd+
Verified • 3rd+
Lt. General - Deputy Chief of Integrated Defence Staff | Strategic Leadership
Lt. General - Deputy Chief of Integrated Defence Staff | Strategic Leadership
“The more you sweat in peace, the less you bleed in war”.

I was reminded of this popular adage from the Army when sharing my
experiences on ‘Performance Under Pressure” with the cohort of extremely
accomplished entrepreneurs at the xto10x IPO Academy off-site at Bengaluru
on 21st March 2025.

Humbling and inspiring to see the already very successful founders and CFOs
‘sweating’ and preparing hard for their super start-ups to go public - no less than going to war, I guess - in corporate parlance!

And a special thank you tofor inviting me and organising an impeccable event.

I led the Marketplace Organisation which was essentially responsible for the platform that brings customers and driver partners together. The team included leaders from product, technology and data science working on problems in supply shaping, demand shaping, pricing and allocation and drove both the growth and profitability objectives for the company.

Bangalore

While at eKart, I focused on building new ops and technology capabilities that helped eKart more than triple consumer reach, dramatically improve speed, improve the network footprint and design, and reduce cost per shipment by >25%. Most of these targets were achieved by the relatively simple task of getting out of the way of an outstanding team!

While at McKinsey, I led the Chemicals and Operations Practices in India and and led the Implementation Service Line for Asia. I worked deeply with Indian companies and MNCs in India on multi-year performance transformation efforts. 

Inevitably, as with everyone at the Firm, I spent a meaningful amount of time in my McKinsey career on strategy and organisation topics, and continue to be a student of both these subjects - essential to getting the recipe right for a high performance organisation.
